clinical_study.brief_title: Education for Osteoporosis in Persons With Existing Fractures

brief_summary.textblock: We wish to investigate whether a weekly, 2½ hour group-based osteoporosis education intervention (the Osteoporosis Prevention and Self-Management Course), is different to one session course (1x 2½ hours) on osteoporosis knowledge, confidence to eat calcium-containing foods, confidence to exercise, and amount of exercise undertaken after three and nine months of follow-up in people aged over 50 years who have already had a bone fracture.

detailed_description.textblock:
Instruments used to determine change after 3 and 9 months:
Osteoporosis knowledge: Osteoporosis Knowledge Assessment Test (Winzenberg et al. BMC Musculoskelet Disord 2003) Calcium intake: Food frequency questionnaire (Angus et al. J Am Diet Assoc 1989) Calcium and exercise self-efficacy: Osteoporosis Self-Efficacy Scale (Horan et al Res Nurs Health 1998) Physical activity: CHAMPS II (Stewart et al. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci 2001)

primary_outcome.measure: Difference between groups at three months on osteoporosis knowledge, confidence in ability to consume calcium and to exercise, actual calcium consumption and exercise levels

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes between baseline and three months within each group on osteoporosis knowledge, confidence in the ability to each calcium-containing foods and exercise, and the amount of calcium consumed in foods and exercise undertaken

arm_group.description: Osteoporosis Prevention and Self-Management Course (4 x 2 1/2 hours)
One "introductory" osteoporosis education session (1 x 2 1/2 hours)

intervention.description: Four weekly education sessions of 2 1/2 hours duration, in a group session facilitated by a community nurse and trained lay leader.
Introductory education session, 1 x 2 1/2 hours in a group session facilitated by a community nurse and trained lay person.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Presented to Modbury Hospital's Accident and Emergency Department with a new bone fracture
Exclusion Criteria:
- Residence in nursing home
- Fracture sustained in motor bike, push bike or motor vehicle accident
- Fracture sustained due to high trauma, such as fall from roof or ladder
- Dementia
- Inability to participate in group settings
- Inability to understand spoken English
- Inability to provide informed consent
- Pathological fracture
- Usual place of residence outside South Australia
